titleStmt.title: The maids prophecies or Englands looking-glasse. Dedicated to both Houses of Parliament, Sir Thomas Fairfax, and the Lord Major of the city of London.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

keywords.term: Great Britain -- History -- Civil War, 1642-1649 -- Prophecies -- Early works to 1800.

2014-07 Maria Cecilia CarideText and markup reviewed and edited

div.head: THE MAIDS PROPHECIES OR ENGLANDS LOOKING-GLASSE. Dedicated to both Houses of PARLIAMENT, Sir Thomas Fairfax, and the Lord-Major of the City of LONDON.

q.p: Prophecying serveth not for them that beleeve not, but for them which beleeve.

lg.l: Despise not Prophesies though by a Maid.
They are pronounst good Sir, be not afraid
Tis worth your money, buy and you shall see
Things that are past, and what must one day be
Here is a parfect metor, wondrous true
Where every one may their perfections view
Come buy this Looking-glass • , tho twill not flatter
If you have honest faces, tis no matter.

div.p: IT is the witty part of a witty Orator to begin his preface with so he pleasing discourse wherewith he may cheane the Eares of his Auditors to his Tongue with most atentive head.

lg.l: But I will with no Syrens voyce inchant you,
Nor shall my language be so rude to dant you.

div.p: Tis not usually to see our Sex in print, but things customary, doe common passe, without regard, but this is the last age of the world, and in the latter dayes the spirit shall be poured out on all flesh:I •• l 2.28. Isa 44.3. Acts 2.17. old men will dreame, young men see strange visions, and Maids prophesie as for Dreames. I understand none but the Elders: neither fe I any visions, but some fine painted Cassells in the Aire built by the Cavaliers: and the shaddow of a very glorious Church founded I know not where, and we may fi • d it I know not when.

lg.l: Some curious soule may question whence I came
what my condition is, or what my name,
but I will tell you true what not I am.

div.p: I am not that wise Woeman, that beat out Abi ••• l • cks brain •• nor Debara amother in Israell, but Cassandra a Daughter in England that would faine beat good counsell into your braines that have worne out your wits like M • ll-stones grinding against one another to rub out a new Religion, which we nor oue Fathers never knew nor heard of.

lg.l: hath fild my soule with a divining spirit,
which bids me tell the Synod they have sit
to find the truth, till they have lost their wit.

div.p: They will hammer so long upon the Anvill of their owne brain, till the sparkles flie into their eyes where they may consume by the same light which themselves have kindled: England hath beene plunged in an unsivill course of ivill Warres so long, for the Lawes of the Land, the priviledge of Parliament, and liberty of the Subject, till the Land hath no Law, the Parliament no priviledge, neither hath the Subject any liberty at all, so much as to serve God publickly or yeld obedience to the King, although we have Christ example to pay him tribute.

But our reverend Synod hath learnedly consulted to reforme the words of our Saviour, the wayes of the Apostles and the works of ancient Fathers. Abolishing all old seremonies with a new directory, to bring us to Heaven a nearer way then the protistant Church could ever have imagined.

Their wisdomes have promised very much, and performed as little, like that labouring mountaine 〈◊〉 brought forth a mou •• to the great amazement of the beholders whose lingring patience
hath been tired with fruitlesse expectation, these wise reformer have been sircumspect in tithing min • and comming, but let sl •• things of weightier matter, they have been soveer to punish Rochets, Surplis, Copes, and Miter, and pluck downe Crosses, Pictures, Organs, Altars, with a gallant new brome to sweep the ragges of Rome out of the church, till at length they will sweep the church out of large windowes, where some of our valiant Souldery have made long breaches, invading the painted • lasse as desperatly as ever Donquickeshot incountred with the Wind-mills.

Twas an act indeed of zeale and valour to fight with Tombes, deface Monuments, and blot out the Commandements, because say They, they are no Rules to walk by, for the wicked have nothing to do to take Gods Law in their mouthes therefore they would not have it before their eyes, this house of Prayer hath beene turned into a Den of theefes, witnesse their often mustring and quartering in severall Churches of this Kingdome, where some on the Lords day sat clouting their shooes, and patching their Coates, prating and making a noyse whilst the Minister was delivering the word of God in the Pulpit, their sacreligious hands have robd and plundered those consecrated Garments wherewith the Priest according to the word should be adorned with desency and honour but they whose power and authority have imployed them to this unwarantable act may be warned by the Eagle in the fable, who, filching a peece of flesh from the Altar brought with a cole wherewith she set her Nest on fire, so these ill gotten goods will frot and wast like a canker till it consume all that partaines of right to the detainers thereof by wrongfullnesse and might, How many honest men and Orthodox Devines for discharging the duty of a good conscience to God and the King, have been persecuted, plundered, sequestred, and imprisoned by them that would have none Lorded over their Brethren, but would levell themselves with the Lords antointed, it is the lot of Gods people to suffer tribulation, Iesabell persecuted the Prophets: Ahab plundred Naboths Vineard, Daniell was cast into the Lyons Den, because he did not forsake his old common prayer for a new Directory, composed by Darious and his Nobles.

It is a sad thing when a tender conscience shall be compeld to make shipwrack of a good faith for Cowardly feare, or base preferment which is worse, for Salmanders which love to live in the fire of contention here who will without repentance live in the
fire unquentionable hereafter they bind heavy burdens with the Pharisee w ••• they will not touch with one of their fingers, they tye us to a government of Presbytery, but let loose the ratignes to licentious liberty, as for me I have binm sled a 6 years progres to find a way to paradice, but have bin m sled with so many Ignus sa • uus by the way that my faitth was tired til at last I fixt upon the old opinion of Pithagoras, and beleeve the Transmigration of the soule from whence I am ass • red the Spirit of the Trojan Princes Cassandra is infufed into me, Whereby I am inspired to prophesie, And sith I am sent, why should I not shew my selfe, yes, that I may do and say nothing, for, Maids should be seen and not heard, neither is it safe to speak all knowe truth.

What then shall I run away and hide my selfe with Jonas; but if I should meet with a tempestious Storme at Sea, and be cast into the close prison of a Whales belly, I were better indure the storm of a Grand Committee, and be cast into some earthly prison by their favourable appointment. Therefore I will stay and deliver my Message.
As Cassandra sent her cryes Through the Streets of Troy so must I through the streets of London,

p.hi: She was a frantick Damsel So am I Or else could have no power to prophesie.
She was the Daughter of an undone Father and Mother,
So is the Kings, And I am no other: Her Prophesies were true, so are mine, but not beleeved no more will mine, but yet her greeved soule did thus divine.

lg.head: Cassandra's Prophesies,
lg.l: Cry Trojans cry a Hellen and a woe
Cry Cry Troy burnes, or else let Hellen go.

div.l: These were her words with whom I Sympathize
which makes me through the City send these Cryes.

Cry London
• ry, a fatall Parliament,
dissolve it quickly or you will repent.
Cry England Cry, a Fairfax and a King,
Advance him to hi • Throne, or Heaven will fling
more plagues on you then the Aegiptians were
whilst you like Pharoh will no threatning feare.
Cry Ireland Cry plung'd in a Sea of woe.
C • y for revenge on them that use the s •
Thou mightst have bin releeved but w • rt neglected
cry till the Authors plots shall be detected
Cry against them that caus'd thy discontent
Cry against London and the Parliament,
That bought and sold their Lands and made them t • y
such desperate meanes with so much cruelty
Cry Scotland Cry that ere your Blew Caps came
to Order us remunerate the same,

Cry
• ocky's Cry for selling of your King,
There is a restoration day will bring
you to account. The Parliament is free
And will reward you for your Loyalty
If you will come your Bretheren to aid
in their distresse you shall be bravely paid
Tis fear'd some will besiege the Directory
come and releive it twill be for your glory
To rescue the Meneran of your braines
which you have prepogated with such paines

Cry England cr •
for driving of your Queen
to sad exile the like hath not bin seen
Cursed be they that parted man and wife
unite them speedily compose the strife
For till the King, Queene Princes all appeare
like constellations fixed in their sphere
Shall never Father, Sonne, Wife, Daughter, Mother
in England find true joy in one another
For they that drove the King from of his throne
shall shorttly have no dwelling of their owne

div.p: Some of those that forced the Queen to go from her Husband shall run from their owne wives; They that compeld the Princely heire of England to leave his father in distresse, shal leave their Children in distraction Confusion flyes throughout all England in strange disguize, Old Jealousies and feares shall newly fall together by the eares but how long shall we hault between two opinions if Charles be King let us obey him if the Parliament he kings let- us feare them. I know there will be cause when the wicked beare rule the people sigh,Pro. 29.2. but when the righteous are in Authority the people rejoyce.

Servants may ride when princes go on foot. I have heard of a Tyrant which tooke four Kings captive compelling them to draw his Charriot, One of them looking back smiled,Eccles. 10.7. which the Tyrant perceiving demanded the cause to whom the dejected King replyed it joyes me to see those spokes of the wheeles which were lowest
advanced to the hi • hest and those which are above to re ••• a • low for which observation he was immediatly released, and tha • we see there is no stability infortune but time and chance haps alike to all 〈…〉 there is not storme but hath his calme: no ebb, but hath his Flood, No winter but hath its Sommer, no Autumn but hath its Spring, no night but hath its day.

Time that makes man miserable, make the same man happy time that Saints hypocrisie with a seeming face of truth will one day pluck of that Vizard and discover their wickednesse to the World who under a pretence of long prayers, devour Widdowes hou • e, professing to do right with Judgement, but have executed Iudgement against all right or reason, Pretending peace like Ioab to Amasa, but working Treasons Time, will strip the sheeps skins over their Wolvish eares who instead of feeding the flock waite an opportunity to destroy them, Time that draw out scandalous Cavaliers Ministers to put in scandalous Presbyter-Ministers wil now supply their places with gifted Independants that were never Ministers, Time payes every one in his owne Coine, and now they may say with Adonibezeck as I have done unto others, so God hath don unto me,

The devill made our Saviours ne •• ssity his opportunity by tempting him with promise of a Kingdome which was not his to give, the Parlia ••• t uses the like temptation to his Majesty. It is said of Satan he forc't him not, he toucht him not, he only said cast thy self downe I • may be said of them they force him and have strove to touch hi •
〈◊〉 if he yeeld to their unreasonable propositions he will cast himself • downe to his utter ruine.

lg.l: A true prediction of his Majesties coming to London,
Char • es shall not injoy his crowne
till •• th houses vot • him downe,
〈◊〉 when th • y have done their worst
He shall be gr 〈…〉 r then at first
time th •• drov • him from his throne
Will restor • him to his one

div.p: His Majesty, was out-witted when he was pers • aded to leave Hampton Court for • ea •• of the Adjut ••• rs but time will put a Trick upon their wits that so cunningly 〈…〉 trayed him.

I am confirmed by Inspiration of the spirit to second Mr. Saltm ••• shes predictions which i • that the Lord is departed from the Army
yet a lying spirit shall deceive them, as it did the King of Israell when he was perswaded to go up and prosper, so shall they go up against the Scots whom the Lord hath stirred up to destroy their ungodly designes. And though there be little good to be expected from those who have bin authors of so much misery yet he that brings light out of darknesse, Good out of evill, will make them instruments of the true protestant deliverance who having been long obscured, shall like the cleere beames of the Sun, breake through these horrid mil • s of error, in spight of opposition being established w • th unity, peace and concord.
The King, Queen, and Prince shall enjoy their former rights and titles, but not without much trouble, because the iniquity of the Amalecks is not yet full.

There shall be much bloud spilt, and that not of the meanest part of Merlins prophesie shall be found about the Marquesse of Worcesters house in Wales which prediction fore-sheweth very high and hidden things, not easily understood, Two shall contest whilst the • hird carrieth the prise, the ban • shed shall be recalled it shall go ill with Ireland, not wel with England, the Spaniard hath a designe against that, the French against this, and the Pope upon both here shall be a great Mortality, many shall dye of the Callenture, others shall dy distracted, laying violent hands on themselves, the pestilence shall increase, a famine shall follow not only of br •• d, nor of flesh, but of the word, the Jewish religion shall abound very much in London, by reason of a false prophet which shall delude them. the Sha • ers and quakers shall declare strange •• velation, but if an • ng • ll from heaven should teach any o • her doctrine then what you have learn'd ye ought not to believe them, Isa 30.2 • .2 • , For though the Lord give you b • ead of adversity and water of afliction, yet shall not thy •••• hers be re ••
ved in to a corner any more but thine eyes shall see thy re •••• ers. For thou shalt heere a voice beh ••• d thee saying this is the way walk in it for till the true protestant Church be established not one in the three divided Kingdomes shall be truly • appy.

p.hi: Time that produced an Order against Scandalous pamphlets will take any the occasion of Scandalous actions when the wood crea ••• the •• e go ••• out.

lg.l: Reforme in time your scandalous abuses
And time shall reconsile our bitter Muses
Jn time do justice to his Majesty
O House of Parliament why will you die?
God and the King will a free pardon give
Except their clemency, break up and live
Jn both their favors be advised by me
VVh • th • s in time conclud my Prophecyes
VVith Swan like long if any s • ek to have
Accomp 〈…〉 me, their find me in my Grave
In tombe without inscult or Ellegie
〈◊〉 that my selfe fo • e ••• s my destinie
This Epitaph with my owne pencill writ
Here lies a peece of strange santastique wit.
Be jolly and prick up your eares
Shake hands an • bid a dew
Now they are twentie mile hench
You need not feare your lives,
Th • ugh no •• e knowes for what
But s • re it must be thought

As that of la ••
• as wrought
That one may run and read
How did my good Lord Major
And Baize from thence he snapt
But then oh, had you seen
In spight of his in • ent
A Gam-ba • ll by his Ga 〈…〉
The Horse still kick't and flung
Threw up th ir Caps with joy
To see my good Lord Major
